Exceptions

This module provides the exception classes used by ProtoBase for different error scenarios.

Exception Hierarchy

ProtoBase defines a hierarchy of exception classes to handle different types of errors:

  • ProtoBaseException: The base class for all ProtoBase exceptions. - ProtoUserException: Base class for exceptions that are expected to be handled by the user.

    • ProtoValidationException: Raised when validation fails.

    • ProtoNotSupportedException: Raised when an operation is not supported.

    • ProtoNotAuthorizedException: Raised when an operation is not authorized.

    • ProtoCorruptionException: Raised when data corruption is detected.

    • ProtoUnexpectedException: Base class for unexpected exceptions. - CloudStorageError: Raised for cloud storage specific errors. - CloudClusterStorageError: Raised for cloud cluster storage specific errors.

Exception Classes

ProtoBaseException

class proto_db.exceptions.ProtoBaseException(code=1, exception_type=None, message=None)[source]

Base exception for ProtoBase exceptions

Parameters:

  • code (int)

  • exception_type (str)

  • message (str)

__init__(code=1, exception_type=None, message=None)[source]
Parameters:

  • code (int)

  • exception_type (str)

  • message (str)

The base class for all ProtoBase exceptions. All other exception classes inherit from this class.

ProtoUserException

class proto_db.exceptions.ProtoUserException(code=20000, exception_type=None, message=None)[source]
Parameters:

  • code (int)

  • exception_type (str)

  • message (str)

__init__(code=20000, exception_type=None, message=None)[source]
Parameters:

  • code (int)

  • exception_type (str)

  • message (str)

Base class for exceptions that are expected to be handled by the user. These exceptions indicate errors in the user’s code or input.

ProtoValidationException

class proto_db.exceptions.ProtoValidationException(code=10000, exception_type=None, message=None)[source]
Parameters:

  • code (int)

  • exception_type (str)

  • message (str)

__init__(code=10000, exception_type=None, message=None)[source]
Parameters:

  • code (int)

  • exception_type (str)

  • message (str)

Raised when validation fails. This can happen when invalid arguments are passed to a method or when an operation would result in an invalid state.

ProtoNotSupportedException

class proto_db.exceptions.ProtoNotSupportedException(code=40000, exception_type=None, message=None)[source]
Parameters:

  • code (int)

  • exception_type (str)

  • message (str)

__init__(code=40000, exception_type=None, message=None)[source]
Parameters:

  • code (int)

  • exception_type (str)

  • message (str)

Raised when an operation is not supported. This can happen when trying to use a feature that is not implemented or not available in the current context.

ProtoNotAuthorizedException

class proto_db.exceptions.ProtoNotAuthorizedException(code=50000, exception_type=None, message=None)[source]

  • code (int)

  • exception_type (str)

  • message (str)

__init__(code=50000, exception_type=None, message=None)[source]
Parameters:

  • code (int)

  • exception_type (str)

  • message (str)

Raised when an operation is not authorized. This can happen when trying to perform an operation that requires higher privileges.

ProtoCorruptionException

class proto_db.exceptions.ProtoCorruptionException(code=30000, exception_type=None, message=None)[source]

  • code (int)

  • exception_type (str)

  • message (str)

__init__(code=30000, exception_type=None, message=None)[source]
Parameters:

  • code (int)

  • exception_type (str)

  • message (str)

Raised when data corruption is detected. This can happen when reading corrupted data from storage or when an internal consistency check fails.

ProtoUnexpectedException

class proto_db.exceptions.ProtoUnexpectedException(code=60000, exception_type=None, message=None)[source]
Parameters:

  • code (int)

  • exception_type (str)

  • message (str)

__init__(code=60000, exception_type=None, message=None)[source]
Parameters:

  • code (int)

  • exception_type (str)

  • message (str)

Base class for unexpected exceptions. These exceptions indicate errors that are not expected to occur in normal operation and may indicate bugs in the code.

CloudStorageError

class proto_db.cloud_file_storage.CloudStorageError(code=60000, exception_type=None, message=None)[source]

Exception raised for cloud storage specific errors.

Parameters:

  • code (int)

  • exception_type (str)

  • message (str)

Raised for cloud storage specific errors. This can happen when there are issues with cloud storage operations (Amazon S3 or Google Cloud Storage) or when the cloud storage is misconfigured.

CloudClusterStorageError

class proto_db.cloud_cluster_file_storage.CloudClusterStorageError(code=60000, exception_type=None, message=None)[source]

Exception raised for cloud cluster storage specific errors.

Parameters:

  • code (int)

  • exception_type (str)

  • message (str)

Raised for cloud cluster storage specific errors. This can happen when there are issues with distributed operations in a cluster environment that uses cloud object storage (Amazon S3 or Google Cloud Storage) as the final storage for data.

Usage Examples

Handling Exceptions

import proto_db
from proto_db.exceptions import ProtoBaseException, ProtoValidationException

try:
    # Perform an operation that might raise an exception
    storage = proto_db.MemoryStorage()
    space = proto_db.ObjectSpace(storage)
    db = space.get_database("test_db")
    tr = db.new_transaction()

    # This will raise a ProtoValidationException if the key is not a string
    tr.set_root_object(123, "value")

    tr.commit()
except ProtoValidationException as e:
    # Handle validation errors
    print(f"Validation error: {e}")
except ProtoBaseException as e:
    # Handle other ProtoBase exceptions
    print(f"ProtoBase error: {e}")
except Exception as e:
    # Handle unexpected exceptions
    print(f"Unexpected error: {e}")
finally:
    # Clean up resources
    if 'storage' in locals():
        storage.close()

Raising Custom Exceptions

You can also define your own exception classes that inherit from the ProtoBase exception classes:

from proto_db.exceptions import ProtoUserException

class MyCustomException(ProtoUserException):
    """
    A custom exception for my application.
    """
    def __init__(self, message, custom_info=None):
        super().__init__(message=message)
        self.custom_info = custom_info

# Raise the custom exception
raise MyCustomException("Something went wrong", custom_info="Additional information")
